Explanation (General): Flashover in the distributor of an aircraft-engine ignition system is a condition in which high voltage leaks from the terminal to ground across the surface of the insulation in the distributor block.|As the high voltage crosses the insulator, it burns, or turns to carbon, any oil or impurity on the surface. This carbon produces a low-resistance path, or conductive trail, for other pulses of voltage to leak across.

Question: What is the relationship between distributor and crankshaft speed of aircraft reciprocating engines?
Answer A: The distributor turns at one-half crankshaft speed.
Answer B: The distributor turns at one and one-half crankshaft speed.
Answer C: The crankshaft turns at one-half distributor speed.
Explanation (General): In order for the distributor to direct high voltage to each of the cylinders in two revolutions of the crankshaft, the distributor rotor must turn at one half of the crankshaft speed.

Question: Why do turbine engine ignition systems require high energy?
Answer A: To ignite the fuel under conditions of high altitude and high temperatures.
Answer B: Because the applied voltage is much greater.
Answer C: To ignite the fuel under conditions of high altitude and low temperatures.
Explanation (General): Turbine-engine ignition systems require much higher energy than the ignition system for a reciprocating engine. The reason is that turbine igniters must be able to consistently ignite the fuel-air mixture under conditions of high altitude and extremely low temperature.

Question: Which of the following are included in a typical turbine engine ignition system?|1. Two igniter plugs.|2. Two transformers.|3. One exciter unit.|4. Two intermediate ignition leads.|5. Two low-tension igniter leads.|6. Two high-tension igniter leads.
Explanation (General): A typical turbine-engine ignition system supplies high voltage to two igniters in the combustors on the opposite sides of the engine. In order to do this, the following components are needed:|1. Two igniter plugs|3. One exciter unit (a dual unit)|6. Two high-tension igniter leads

Question: At what RPM is a reciprocating engine ignition switch check made?
Answer C: Full throttle RPM.
Explanation (General): The ignition switch check for a reciprocating engine is made at the slowest possible RPM.|The engine is idled and the ignition switch is turned to the OFF position to see if the engine will stop running.|As soon as it is determined that the switch does ground out both magnetos, the switch is returned to the BOTH position.|If the engine is operating at a high RPM when this test is made, there is a possibility of a backfire that will damage the exhaust system.

Question: What is the approximate position of the rotating magnet in a high-tension magneto when the points first close?
Answer C: A few degrees after neutral.
Explanation (General): The breaker points in a high-tension magneto open when the rotating magnet is in its E-gap position. In this position, the magnet is just beyond its neutral position.|The breaker points close when the magnet is approximately in its full register position. In this position, the poles of the magnet are aligned with the pole shoes.

Question: What component of a dual magneto is shared by both ignition systems?
Answer C: Capacitor.
Explanation (General): A dual, or double magneto, has a single rotating magnet, but it has two sets of breaker points, two high-tension coils and two capacitors.|A double magneto has two sets of breaker points, two coils and two condensers.

Question: What would be the result if a magneto breaker point mainspring did not have sufficient tension?
Answer B: The points will not open to the specified gap.
Answer C: The points will float or bounce.
Explanation (General): If the breaker-point mainspring (the spring on which the movable breaker point is mounted) does not have sufficient tension, the points will float or bounce. This can cause the engine to miss at high speed.

Question: The secondary coil of a magneto is grounded through the
Answer C: grounded side of the breaker points.
Explanation (General): The coil of a high-tension magneto is made of a primary coil wound of several layers of fairly heavy wire over a laminated steel core.|One end of the primary coil is grounded to the core. The other end is carried out to the pigtail that goes to the condenser and the breaker points.|The secondary coil is made of many turns of fine wire. It is wound on top of the primary coil. One end of the secondary coil is connected to the primary coil and the other end is carried out of the coil at the high-tension terminal that connects to the distributor rotor.

Question: In the aircraft magneto system, if the P-lead is disconnected, the magneto will be
Answer A: on regardless of ignition switch position.
Answer B: grounded regardless of ignition switch position.
Answer C: open regardless of ignition switch position.
Explanation (General): If the P-lead is disconnected from a magneto, the magneto will be 'hot,' or ON, regardless of the position of the ignition switch.

Question: (Refer to Figure 5.) With power applied to the bus bar, what switch changes will allow the ignition exciters test switch to function?
Answer A: Engine master switch, battery switch, and power lever switch.
Answer B: Engine master switch, start switch, and test switch.
Answer C: Engine master switch and ignition switch.
Explanation (General): When power is supplied to the bus, the ignition exciters test switch will function when the following switches are changed:|__bullet__ The engine master switch must be ON, in its up position.|__bullet__ The ignition switch must be ON, in its up position.

Question: (Refer to Figure 5.) The type of system depicted is capable of operating with
Answer C: battery power and external power simultaneously.
Explanation (General): This electrical system can be operated by either the ship's battery or by an external power supply, but not by both at the same time. When the plug is inserted into the external power receptacle it opens the receptacle switch and stops current flow through the battery relay coil. The battery relay opens, disconnecting the battery from the system. This prevents both power sources being connected to the system at the same time.

Question: (Refer to Figure 5.) If wire No. 8 is broken or disconnected after starter rotation is initiated, and the power lever is advanced, the
Answer B: starter will shut down, but the igniters will continue to fire.
Answer C: starting sequence will discontinue.
Explanation (General): If wire number 8 is broken after the start sequence has begun, the starting sequence will continue normally.|Wire 8 supplies current to the starter relay coil, but when the starter relay contacts are closed, current flowing through the series starter coils in the starter generator causes the coil in the undercurrent relay to produce a strong enough field to close its contacts. Current from the bus flowing through the undercurrent relay contacts holds the starter relay coil energized, and the start sequence continues normally.|When the start switch is placed in the down, or STOP, position, or when the starter-generator requires too little current to hold the undercurrent relay closed, the starter relay contacts will open and discontinue the start sequence.

Question: (Refer to Figure 5.) When an external power source is connected to the aircraft,
Answer A: the battery cannot be connected to the bus.
Answer B: both battery power and external power are available to the bus.
Answer C: the starter relay coil has a path to ground.
Explanation (General): The way Figure 5 is drawn, both battery power and external power appear to be available to the bus at the same time. Figure 5 does not show what operates the external power receptacle switch, but this switch is automatically opened when the plug is inserted into the external power receptacle. When the external power receptacle switch is open, current cannot flow through the coil of the battery solenoid. This prevents both power sources being connected to the system at the same time.

Question: The purpose of an under current relay in a starter-generator system is to
Answer A: provide a backup for the starter relay.
Answer B: disconnect power from the starter-generator and ignition when sufficient engine speed is reached.
Answer C: keep current flow to the starter-generator under the circuit capacity maximum.
Explanation (General): The start procedure is begun by momentarily closing the start switch. Current flowing through this switch provides current to close the starter relay. When this relay closes, current flows through the series starter windings in the starter generator.|The high current required for starting the engine turning is enough to hold the undercurrent relay closed and supply current to the coil of the starter relay and the ignition relay.|When the engine starts, the current through the series starter winding decreases enough that the undercurrent relay will no longer remain closed. The starter and the ignition relay contacts will open, disconnecting current to the starter winding and de-energizing the ignition exciters.

Question: In a typical starter-generator system, under which of the following starting circumstances may it be necessary to use the start stop button?
Answer C: Contacts stick open.
Explanation (General): The undercurrent relay will terminate the start procedure when the engine starts and the current through the series start windings in the starter generator drops to a predetermined low value.|The stop relay contacts are in series with the contacts of the undercurrent relay. When start switch is moved to the STOP position, it energizes the stop relay and opens the circuit to the starter relay coil and the ignition relay coil.|It may be necessary to use the start stop switch in the event of a hung start. A hung start is one in which ignition occurs but the RPM does not build up enough for the undercurrent relay to open.

Question: (Refer to Figure 5.) Which malfunctions will allow the igniters to operate when tested but be inoperative during a start attempt?|1. Conductor No. 10 broken.|2. Conductor No. 11 broken.|3. Ignition relay inoperative.|4. Conductor No. 12 broken.
Answer C: 1 or 3.
Explanation (General): The igniters will operate when the test switch is closed but will fail to operate during a normal start attempt if there is an open in wire 10 which supplies current to the coil of the ignition relay, or if the ignition relay itself is inoperative.

Question: (Refer to Figure 5.) Which malfunctions will allow the igniters to operate normally during start but be inoperative when tested?|1. Conductor No. 14 broken.|2. Conductor No. 10 broken.|3. Conductor No. 15 broken.|4. Conductor No. 12 broken.
Answer C: 3 or 4.
Explanation (General): The igniters will operate during a normal start, but will be inoperative when the test switch is closed if there is an open in either wire 14 or 15.

Question: When using an electric starter motor, current usage
Answer A: is highest at the start of motor rotation.
Answer B: remains relatively constant throughout the starting cycle.
Answer C: is highest just before starter cutoff (at highest RPM).
Explanation (General): Electric starter motors are series wound for their high starting torque. When the start switch is first closed, the current is very high, but as the motor begins to turn and produce a counter electromotive force, the current decreases.

Question: When using an electric starter motor, the current flow through it
Answer A: is highest just before starter cutoff (at highest RPM).
Answer B: remains relatively constant throughout the starting cycle.
Answer C: is highest at the start of motor rotation.
Explanation (General): Electric starter motors are series wound for their high starting torque. When the start switch is first closed, the current flow is at it highest, and the battery voltage drops considerably. As the motor begins to turn and produce a counter electromotive force, the current decreases.

Question: The primary advantage of pneumatic (air turbine) starters over comparable electric starters for turbine engines is
Answer C: high power-to-weight ratio.
Explanation (General): The primary advantage of an air turbine starter is its high power-to-weight ratio. An air turbine starter weighs approximately one fifth of that of an electric starter that produces an equivalent torque.

Question: A clicking sound heard at engine coast-down in a pneumatic starter incorporating a sprag clutch ratchet assembly is an indication of
Answer B: one or more broken pawl springs.
Answer C: the pawls re-contacting and riding on the ratchet gear.
Explanation (General): A pneumatic starter has a sprag clutch with a ratchet that automatically disengages the starter when the engine starts. Centrifugal force holds the pawls away from the ratchet while the engine is running.|When the engine is shut down and is coasting to a stop, the centrifugal force becomes too low to hold the pawls disengaged, and they will produce a clicking sound as they ride over the ratchet.

Question: Pneumatic starters are usually designed with what types of airflow impingement systems?
Answer A: Radial inward flow turbine and axial-flow turbine.
Answer C: Double entry centrifugal outward flow and axial-flow turbines.
Explanation (General): Pneumatic starters may have an air impingement system of either the radial inflow turbine or the axial flow turbine type.

Question: Inspection of pneumatic starters by maintenance technicians usually includes checking the
Answer A: oil level and magnetic drain plug condition.
Answer B: stator and rotor blades for FOD.
Answer C: rotor alignment.
Explanation (General): Air turbine starters rotate at a speed of between 60,000 and 80,000 RPM, and lubrication provided by an integral oil supply is extremely important. Checking the oil level and the condition of the magnetic drain plug are important parts of routine starter maintenance.

Question: Air turbine starters are generally designed so that reduction gear distress or damage may be detected by
Answer A: characteristic sounds from the starter assembly during engine start.
Answer B: breakage of a shear section on the starter drive shaft.
Answer C: inspection of a magnetic chip detector.
Explanation (General): Air turbine starters have their own self-contained lubrication system with the oil held in the starter housing.|A magnetic chip detector is incorporated into the drain plug to warn the technician of any gear distress that produces flakes or shavings of metal.

Question: Airflow to the pneumatic starter from a ground unit is normally prevented from causing starter overspeed during engine start by
Answer A: stator nozzle design that chokes airflow and stabilizes turbine wheel speed.
Answer B: activation of a flyweight cutout switch.
Answer C: a preset timed cutoff of the airflow at the source.
Explanation (General): If the ground power unit supplies enough compressed air to the pneumatic starter to cause it to overspeed, a centrifugal cutout de-energizes the solenoid and the butterfly valve returns to its closed position, shutting off the air to the starter.

Question: A safety feature usually employed in pneumatic starters that is used if the clutch does not release from the engine drive at the proper time during start is the
Answer C: drive shaft shear point.
Explanation (General): If the clutch in a pneumatic starter does not release when the engine starts, the engine will drive the starter to an excessively high speed. If this happens, a shear section in the drive shaft will break and prevent the engine driving the starter to destruction.

Question: A safety feature usually employed in direct-cranking starters that is used to prevent the starter from reaching burst speed is the
Answer B: stator nozzle design that chokes airflow and stabilizes turbine wheel speed.
Answer C: spring coupling release.
Explanation (General): If the inlet air driving a direct-cranking starter does not terminate on schedule, the design of the inlet air passage will cause the nozzle to become choked and the turbine wheel will stabilize in an overspeed condition rather than continuing to accelerate and destroy itself.

Question: In the event a pneumatic start valve will not operate and the manual override must be used, the starter T-handle must be closed at scheduled starter drop out because
Answer B: the starter will overspeed at a given N^2.
Answer C: the starter oil will be blown overboard.
Explanation (General): When manually operating an air turbine starter by using the T-handle, it is important that the T-handle be turned to the CLOSED position when the N^2 reaches a specified RPM. If the valve is not closed at this time, the starter will overspeed.

Question: What factor is not used in the operation of an aircraft gas turbine engine fuel control unit?
Answer C: Power lever position.
Explanation (General): The fuel-control unit on an aircraft gas turbine engine senses, among other parameters, compressor inlet air temperature and power lever position.|Gas turbine engines do not have a mixture control.

Question: In order to stabilize cams, springs, and linkages within the fuel control, manufacturers generally recommend that all final turbine engine trim adjustments be made in the
Answer C: decrease direction after over-adjustment.
Explanation (General): When trimming a turbine engine fuel control, to stabilize the cams, springs, and linkages, all the final adjustments must be made in the increase direction.

Question: When trimming a turbine engine, the fuel control is adjusted to
Answer A: produce as much power as the engine is capable of producing.
Answer B: set idle RPM and maximum speed or EPR.
Answer C: allow the engine to produce maximum RPM without regard to power output.
Explanation (General): Trimming a turbine engine means adjusting the fuel control unit to set the idle RPM and the maximum speed or EPR of the engine.

Question: A supervisory electronic engine control (EEC) is a system that receives engine operating information and
Answer A: adjusts a standard hydromechanical fuel control unit to obtain the most effective engine operation.
Answer B: develops the commands to various actuators to control engine parameters.
Answer C: controls engine operation according to ambient temperature, pressure, and humidity.
Explanation (General): A supervisory electronic engine control (EEC) receives its engine operating data from sensors in the engine and controls a hydromechanical fuel control unit to obtain the most effective engine operation.

Question: A full-authority electronic engine control (EEC) is a system that receives all the necessary data for engine operation and
Answer A: adjusts a standard hydromechanical fuel control unit to obtain the most effective engine operation.
Answer B: develops the commands to various actuators to control engine parameters.
Answer C: controls engine operation according to ambient temperature, pressure, and humidity.
Explanation (General): A full-authority electronic engine control (EEC) performs all of the functions necessary to operate a turbofan engine most efficiently and safely in all modes of operation. This includes starting, accelerating, decelerating, takeoff, climb, cruise, and idle. It receives data from the aircraft and engine systems, provides data for the aircraft systems, and issues commands to the engine control actuators.

Question: In a supervisory EEC system, any fault in the EEC that adversely affects engine operation
Answer A: causes redundant or backup units to take over and continue normal operation.
Answer B: usually degrades performance to the extent that continued operation can cause damage to the engine.
Answer C: causes an immediate reversion to control by the hydromechanical fuel control unit.
Explanation (General): A safety feature of a supervisory ECC is that if any fault occurs which adversely affects the engine operation, the system will immediately revert the control to the hydromechanical control unit.

Question: The active clearance control (ACC) portion of an EEC system aids turbine engine efficiency by
Answer A: adjusting stator vane position according to operating conditions and power requirements.
Answer B: ensuring turbine blade to engine case clearances are kept to a minimum by controlling case temperatures.
Answer C: automatically adjusting engine speed to maintain a desired EPR.
Explanation (General): The active clearance control (ACC) portion of an ECC aids in maintaining peak engine efficiency by ensuring that the compressor and turbine blade clearances are kept to a minimum, thus reducing pressure losses due to leakage at the blade tips. This is done by the ACC directing cooling air through passages in the engine case to control engine case temperature, and thus the expansion of the case.

Question: What should be checked/changed to ensure the validity of a turbine engine performance check if an alternate fuel is to be used?
Answer C: EPR gauge calibration.
Explanation (General): Different turbine-engine fuels have different heat energy content. When making a run-up for a performance check, the fuel specific gravity setting on the fuel control must be changed to give validity to the check.

Question: The generally acceptable way to obtain accurate on-site temperature prior to performing engine trimming is to
Answer A: call the control tower to obtain field temperature.
Answer B: observe the reading on the aircraft Outside Air Temperature (OAT) gauge.
Answer C: hang a thermometer in the shade of the nose wheel-well until the temperature reading stabilizes.
Explanation (General): Accurate temperature is critical when trimming a turbine engine. To determine the temperature at the engine inlet, it is a good policy to hang a thermometer in the shade of the nose wheel-well until its temperature reading stabilizes. Use this as the actual ambient temperature.

Question: An aircraft should be facing into the wind when trimming an engine. However, if the velocity of the wind blowing into the intake is excessive, it is likely to cause a
Answer A: false low exhaust gas temperature reading.
Answer B: trim setting resulting in engine overspeed.
Answer C: false high compression and turbine discharge pressure, and a subsequent low trim.
Explanation (General): If the wind blowing into the engine inlet while trimming the fuel control is excessive, the compression and turbine discharge pressures will be too high. When the engine is operated with the normal amount of wind flowing into it, the trimmed conditions will be too low.

Question: Generally, the practice when trimming an engine is to
Answer A: turn all accessory bleed air off.
Answer B: turn all accessory bleed air on.
Answer C: make adjustments (as necessary) for all engines on the same aircraft with accessory bleed air settings the same -- either on or off.
Explanation (General): When trimming a turbine engine, all of the overboard air valves should be closed and all of the accessory air bleed must be turned off.

Question: A reciprocating engine automatic mixture control responds to changes in air density caused by changes in
Answer C: altitude or temperature.
Explanation (General): An automatic mixture control in a pressure carburetor or fuel injection system responds to changes in air density that are caused by changes in both altitude and temperature.|As either altitude or temperature increases, the air becomes less dense, and the AMC decreases the amount of fuel metered to the engine to keep the fuel-air mixture ratio constant.

Question: On a float-type carburetor, the purpose of the economizer valve is to
Answer A: provide extra fuel for sudden acceleration of the engine.
Answer B: maintain the leanest mixture possible during cruising best power.
Answer C: provide a richer mixture and cooling at maximum power output.
Explanation (General): An economizer system, also called a power enrichment system, provides additional fuel at full power operation to remove some of the excess heat from the cylinders.|This system is called an economizer system because it allows an economical operation at conditions other than full power.

Question: The fuel metering force of a conventional float-type carburetor in its normal operating range is the difference between the pressure acting on the discharge nozzle located within the venturi and the pressure
Answer A: acting on the fuel in the float chamber.
Answer B: of the fuel as it enters the carburetor.
Answer C: of the air as it enters the venturi (impact pressure).
Explanation (General): The fuel-metering force in a float-type carburetor is the pressure difference between the pressure in the float bowl and the pressure at the discharge nozzle which is located in the venturi.|The low pressure at the discharge nozzle is determined by the amount of air flowing into the engine through the venturi.

Question: If the main air bleed of a float-type carburetor becomes clogged, the engine will run
Answer C: rich at idling.
Explanation (General): A clogged main air bleed will cause the mixture to be too rich at the rated power of the engine.|It will have no effect on the mixture at idling because the idling system does not use the main air bleed.

Question: Which method is commonly used to adjust the level of a float in a float-type carburetor?
Answer A: Lengthening or shortening the float shaft.
Answer B: Add or remove shims under the needle-valve seat.
Answer C: Change the angle of the float arm pivot.
Explanation (General): A widely used method of adjusting the float level on a float-type carburetor is by adding or removing shims under the needle-valve seat.

Question: What is the possible cause of an engine running rich at full throttle if it is equipped with a float-type carburetor?
Answer C: Clogged atmospheric vent.
Explanation (General): A clogged main air bleed will cause an engine to run too rich at full throttle.|This principle of restricting the main air bleed at full throttle operation is used in some carburetors as a power-enrichment system.

Question: One of the things a metering orifice in a main air bleed helps to accomplish (at a given altitude) in a carburetor is
Answer A: pressure in the float chamber to increase as airflow through the carburetor increases.
Answer B: a progressively richer mixture as airflow through the carburetor increases.
Answer C: better fuel vaporization and control of fuel discharge, especially at lower engine speeds.
Explanation (General): A metering orifice in the main air bleed of a float-type carburetor meters the correct amount of air into the fuel just before it reaches the main discharge nozzle. This air emulsifies the fuel to decrease its density and make it easier to vaporize, especially at the lower engine speeds.

Question: A punctured float in a float-type carburetor will cause the fuel level to
Answer C: rise, and lean the mixture.
Explanation (General): A punctured float, in a float-type carburetor, will allow fuel to enter the float, making it less buoyant. The fuel will have to rise to a higher level in the float bowl to shut the fuel off.|This higher level of fuel in the float bowl will enrich the mixture.

Question: The back-suction mixture control system operates by
Answer A: varying the pressure within the venturi section.
Answer B: varying the pressure acting on the fuel in the float chamber.
Answer C: changing the effective cross-sectional area of the main metering orifice (jet).
Explanation (General): The back-suction mixture control changes the fuel-air mixture ratio by varying the pressure on the top of the fuel in the float bowl.|Lowering the pressure on this fuel leans the mixture.

Question: If an aircraft engine is equipped with a carburetor that is not compensated for altitude and temperature variations, the fuel/air mixture will become
Answer A: leaner as either the altitude or temperature increases.
Answer B: richer as the altitude increases and leaner as the temperature increases.
Answer C: richer as either the altitude or temperature increases.
Explanation (General): A noncompensated carburetor (a carburetor that cannot be adjusted for mixture changes with altitude) will produce a richer mixture as the air density decreases because of an increase in either altitude or temperature.|The reason for this enrichment is that the carburetor meters the fuel according to the volume of air, but the engine burns it according to its weight.|The weight of a given volume of air decreases as both altitude and temperature increase, so the mixture becomes richer.

Question: Float-type carburetors which are equipped with economizers are normally set for
Answer A: their richest mixture delivery and leaned by means of the economizer system.
Answer B: the economizer system to supplement the main system supply at all engine speeds above idling.
Answer C: their leanest practical mixture delivery at cruising speeds and enriched by means of the economizer system at higher power settings.
Explanation (General): A carburetor equipped with an economizer system is adjusted so the mixture will be sufficiently lean for economical operation under all conditions other than full power.|Under full power conditions, the economizer system adds fuel to enrich the mixture enough that detonation will not occur.

Question: If a float-type carburetor becomes flooded, the condition is most likely caused by
Answer A: a leaking needle valve and seat assembly.
Answer B: the accelerating pump shaft being stuck.
Answer C: a clogged back-suction line.
Explanation (General): If a needle valve and seat assembly in a float-type carburetor leaks, the fuel level will rise above the discharge level of the main discharge nozzle and the carburetor will become flooded.

Question: If an engine is equipped with a float-type carburetor and the engine runs excessively rich at full throttle, a possible cause of the trouble is a clogged
Answer C: atmospheric vent line.
Explanation (General): Under full-throttle operation, the main air bleed must introduce enough air into the fuel to prevent the mixture becoming excessively rich.|If this air bleed becomes restricted, or clogged, the engine will run excessively rich at wide-open throttle.|The power enrichment system used on some float-type carburetors enriches the mixture at full power by restricting the main air bleed.

Question: What occurs when a back-suction type mixture control is placed in IDLE CUTOFF?
Answer A: The fuel passages to the main and idle jets will be closed by a valve.
Answer B: The float chamber will be vented to a negative pressure area.
Answer C: The fuel passage to the idle jet will be closed by a valve.
Explanation (General): The back-suction mixture control regulates the fuel-air mixture by varying the pressure above the fuel in the float chamber.|When this type of carburetor is placed in the IDLE CUTOFF position, the float chamber is vented to a negative pressure.

Question: Which of the following best describes the function of an altitude mixture control?
Answer A: Regulates the richness of the fuel/air charge entering the engine.
Answer B: Regulates the air pressure above the fuel in the float chamber.
Answer C: Regulates the air pressure in the venturi.
Explanation (General): An altitude mixture control allows the pilot to maintain a fuel-air mixture ratio entering the engine that will produce the desired engine operation.|This is the same as regulating the richness of the fuel-air charge entering the engine.

Question: Select the correct statement concerning the idle system of a conventional float-type carburetor.
Answer A: The low-pressure area created in the throat of the venturi pulls the fuel from the idle passage.
Answer B: Climatic conditions have very little effect on idle mixture requirements.
Answer C: The low pressure between the edges of the throttle valve and the throttle body pulls the fuel from the idle passage.
Explanation (General): In a conventional float-type carburetor at idle, there is not enough air flowing through the venturi to pull fuel from the main discharge nozzle.|The idle discharge nozzle is located in the throttle body at the edge of the throttle valve, and all of the air flowing into the engine for idling must pass between the edges of the throttle valve and the throttle body. It produces a low pressure that pulls the fuel-air emulsion from the idle passage.

Question: On an engine equipped with a pressure-type carburetor, fuel supply in the idling range is ensured by the inclusion in the carburetor of
Answer A: a spring in the unmetered fuel chamber to supplement the action of normal metering forces.
Answer B: an idle metering jet that bypasses the carburetor in the idle range.
Answer C: a separate boost venturi that is sensitive to the reduced airflow at start and idle speeds.
Explanation (General): In a pressure carburetor, there is a spring in the unmetered fuel chamber that holds the poppet valve slightly off its seat to ensure a uniform flow of fuel under conditions of low airflow.

Question: The economizer system of a float-type carburetor performs which of the following functions?
Answer A: It supplies and regulates the fuel required for all engine speeds.
Answer B: It supplies and regulates the additional fuel required for all engine speeds above cruising.
Answer C: It regulates the fuel required for all engine speeds and all altitudes.
Explanation (General): The economizer system on a float-type carburetor adds additional fuel to that which is metered through the main metering jet at all conditions above cruise.|It is for this reason that economizer systems are often called power enrichment systems.

Question: How will the mixture of an engine be affected if the bellows of the automatic mixture control (AMC) in a pressure carburetor ruptures while the engine is operating at altitude?
Answer B: No change will occur until the altitude changes.
Answer C: It will become richer.
Explanation (General): In a pressure-injection carburetor, air from the impact tubes flows past the automatic mixture control (AMC) needle valve, into chamber A of the regulator and out through mixture control bleeds into chamber B.|Pressure of an inert gas inside the AMC bellows is balanced by a spring force that tries to collapse the bellows and open the passage.|As the aircraft goes up in altitude, atmospheric pressure on the outside of the bellows decreases. The pressure of the gas inside the AMC overcomes the spring pressure enough to close the needle valve and restrict the flow of air. This causes the air metering force to lean the mixture progressively as altitude increases.|If the bellows ruptures and allows the inert gas to escape from the AMC unit, the spring will pull the needle back, opening the passage and allowing a full flow of impact air into chamber A. This will increase the air metering force and open the poppet valve, allowing the mixture to become richer.

Question: The fuel level within the float chamber of a properly adjusted float-type carburetor will be
Answer A: slightly higher than the discharge nozzle outlet.
Answer B: slightly lower than the discharge nozzle outlet.
Answer C: at the same level as the discharge nozzle outlet.
Explanation (General): The fuel level of a properly adjusted float-type carburetor will be slightly lower than the discharge nozzle outlet. This prevents fuel flowing out of the discharge nozzle when the aircraft is sitting in a level-ground attitude.

Question: The metered fuel pressure (chamber C) in an injection-type carburetor
Answer A: is held constant throughout the entire engine operating range.
Answer B: varies according to the position of the poppet valve located between chamber D (unmetered fuel) and chamber E (engine-driven fuel pump pressure).
Answer C: will be approximately equal to the pressure in chamber A (impact pressure).
Explanation (General): Metered fuel pressure in chamber C of a pressure-injection carburetor is held constant by a constant-pressure discharge valve. This pressure acts as a reference pressure.|The total metering force is made up of the air metering force across the air diaphragm between chambers A and B and the fuel metering force across the fuel diaphragm between chambers C and D.|The fuel metering force is a balance between the unmetered, but regulated, fuel pressure in chamber D and the metered fuel pressure in chamber C, which is held constant throughout the engine operating range.

Question: Select the statement which is correct relating to a fuel level check of a float-type carburetor.
Answer A: Use 5 pounds fuel pressure for the test if the carburetor is to be used in a gravity fuel feed system.
Answer B: Block off the main and idle jets to prevent a continuous flow of fuel through the jets.
Answer C: Do not measure the level at the edge of the float chamber.
Explanation (General): The fuel level must not be measured at the edge of the float chamber because of the tendency of the fuel to wet the walls of the chamber. At the wall, the fuel will be slightly higher than it is in the center.|A straightedge should be placed across the parting surface of the float bowl and the level measured away from the edge and away from the float.

Question: What carburetor component measures the amount of air delivered to the engine?
Answer C: Venturi.
Explanation (General): A venturi is used to measure the amount of the air pulled into the cylinders of an engine.|The pressure drop in the throat of a venturi is directly proportional to the velocity of the air flowing through it.

Question: If a float-type carburetor leaks fuel when the engine is stopped, a likely cause is that the
Answer A: float needle valve is worn or otherwise not seated properly.
Answer B: float level is adjusted too low.
Answer C: main air bleed is clogged.
Explanation (General): A float-type carburetor leaking when the engine is stopped is caused by fuel rising in the float bowl to a level higher than the tip of the fuel discharge nozzle.|A leaking needle valve is the most likely cause of the fuel level rising when the engine is not running.

Question: Fuel is discharged for idling speeds on a float-type carburetor
Answer C: through the idle discharge air bleed.
Explanation (General): In a float-type carburetor at idle speed, fuel is discharged from the idle discharge nozzle which is located opposite the throttle valve in the carburetor throat.

Question: When air passes through the venturi of a carburetor, what three changes occur?
Answer A: Velocity increases, temperature increases, and pressure decreases.
Answer B: Velocity decreases, temperature increases, and pressure increases.
Answer C: Velocity increases, temperature decreases, and pressure decreases.
Explanation (General): When air passes through a venturi, its velocity increases, and both its temperature and pressure decrease.

Question: Where is the throttle valve located on a float-type carburetor?
Answer A: Between the venturi and the discharge nozzle.
Answer B: After the main discharge nozzle and venturi.
Answer C: After the venturi and just before the main discharge nozzle.
Explanation (General): The throttle valve in a float-type carburetor is located after (downstream of) the main discharge nozzle and the venturi.|The discharge nozzle is located in the venturi.

Question: An aircraft carburetor is equipped with a mixture control in order to prevent the mixture from becoming too
Answer C: rich at high speeds.
Explanation (General): An aircraft carburetor is equipped with a mixture control to prevent the fuel-air mixture from becoming too rich as the aircraft goes up in altitude and the air becomes less dense.

Question: Which of the following is NOT a function of the carburetor venturi?
Answer C: Limits the airflow at full throttle.
Explanation (General): The carburetor venturi has nothing to do with regulating the idle system of the carburetor.|The venturi does proportion the fuel/air mixture and limits the airflow at full throttle.

Question: Idle cutoff is accomplished on a carburetor equipped with a back-suction mixture control by
Answer A: introducing low pressure (intake manifold) air into the float chamber.
Answer B: turning the fuel selector valve to OFF.
Answer C: the positive closing of a needle and seat.
Explanation (General): Idle cutoff in a carburetor equipped with a back-suction mixture control is accomplished by introducing low-pressure air (suction) into the float chamber.|This low pressure lowers the level of fuel in the discharge nozzle so much that the low pressure caused by air flowing through the venturi cannot pull fuel from it.

Question: One purpose of an air bleed in a float-type carburetor is to
Answer B: meter air to adjust the mixture.
Answer C: decrease fuel density and destroy surface tension.
Explanation (General): An air bleed in a float-type carburetor mixes air in the fuel between the metering jet and the discharge nozzle. This decreases the density of the fuel and destroys its surface tension, resulting in better vaporization and control of fuel discharge, especially at lower engine speeds.

Question: To determine the float level in a float-type carburetor, a measurement is usually made from the top of the fuel in the float chamber to the
Answer C: centerline of the main discharge nozzle.
Explanation (General): The fuel level in the float bowl of a float-type carburetor is measured between the parting surface of the carburetor float bowl and the surface of the fuel in the bowl measured at a point away from both the float chamber wall and the float.

Question: The throttle valve of float-type aircraft carburetors is located
Answer A: ahead of the venturi and main discharge nozzle.
Answer B: after the main discharge nozzle and ahead of the venturi.
Answer C: between the venturi and the engine.
Explanation (General): The throttle valve in a float-type carburetor is a butterfly-type valve located between the venturi and the engine.

Question: Why must a float-type carburetor supply a rich mixture during idle?
Answer A: Engine operation at idle results in higher than normal volumetric efficiency.
Answer B: Because at idling speeds the engine may not have enough airflow around the cylinders to provide proper cooling.
Answer C: Because of reduced mechanical efficiency during idle.
Explanation (General): The idle mixture is considerably richer than a normal mixture because at idling speeds the mixture distribution is sometimes uneven, and the engine may not have enough airflow around the cylinders to provide proper cooling.

Question: What component is used to ensure fuel delivery during periods of rapid engine acceleration?
Answer C: Power enrichment unit.
Explanation (General): An accelerator system usually contains an accelerator pump to provide a momentarily rich mixture during periods of rapid engine acceleration.|Under these conditions, the normal metering system is unable to provide an adequately rich mixture.

Question: The device that controls the ratio of the fuel/air mixture to the cylinders is called a
Answer C: metering jet.
Explanation (General): Most aircraft reciprocating engines are equipped with a mixture control that allows the pilot to control the fuel-air mixture ratio as it enters the cylinders of the engine.

Question: The device that controls the volume of the fuel/air mixture to the cylinders is called a
Answer C: throttle valve.
Explanation (General): The throttle valve in a carburetor determines the volume of fuel-air mixture allowed to enter the cylinders.

Question: Which statement is correct regarding a continuous-flow fuel injection system used on many reciprocating engines?
Answer A: Fuel is injected directly into each cylinder.
Answer B: Fuel is injected at each cylinder intake port.
Answer C: Two injector nozzles are used in the injector fuel system for various speeds.
Explanation (General): A continuous-flow fuel injection system delivers a continuous flow of metered fuel to the intake port of each cylinder and not into the combustion chambers.

Question: During the operation of an aircraft engine, the pressure drop in the carburetor venturi depends primarily upon the
Answer C: air velocity.
Explanation (General): The pressure drop in the venturi of a carburetor is a function of the velocity of the air flowing into the engine.|The relationship between pressure and velocity in a stream of moving fluid is explained by Bernoulli's principle.

Question: Which of the following causes a single diaphragm accelerator pump to discharge fuel?
Answer A: An increase in venturi suction when the throttle valve is open.
Answer B: An increase in manifold pressure that occurs when the throttle valve is opened.
Answer C: A decrease in manifold pressure that occurs when the throttle valve is opened.
Explanation (General): When the throttle is suddenly opened, there is an increase in manifold pressure (less suction).|The lack of suction on the diaphragm allows the spring to push the diaphragm over and force the fuel in the accelerator pump chamber out into the airstream.

Question: At what engine speed does the main metering jet actually function as a metering jet in a float-type carburetor?
Answer C: All RPM's above idle range.
Explanation (General): The main metering jet in a float-type carburetor functions as a metering jet at all RPMs above the idling range.|In the idling range, the idling metering jet meters the fuel.

Question: An aircraft engine continuous cylinder fuel injection system normally discharges fuel during which stroke(s)?
Answer C: All (continuously).
Explanation (General): A continuous-flow, fuel injection system discharges fuel during all of the strokes. This is the reason this type of system is called a continuous-flow system.

Question: What is the purpose of the carburetor accelerating system?
Answer A: Supply and regulate the fuel required for engine speeds above idle.
Answer B: Temporarily enrich the mixture when the throttle is suddenly opened.
Answer C: Supply and regulate additional fuel required for engine speeds above cruising.
Explanation (General): There is normally a temporary lag between the time the throttle is opened and the time the engine builds up its speed.|This lag is due to the time required to transition between the idle system and the main metering system.|To prevent this lag, most carburetors are equipped with an accelerating system that provides a momentarily rich mixture during this transition time.

Question: When troubleshooting an engine for too rich a mixture to allow the engine to idle, what would be a possible cause?
Answer C: Air leak in the intake manifold.
Explanation (General): If the engine will not idle because the mixture is too rich, and the idle mixture adjustment on the carburetor will not lean it sufficiently, there is a possibility that the economizer valve is not operating correctly and feeding fuel into the engine.

Question: What is the relationship between the accelerating pump and the enrichment valve in a pressure injection carburetor?
Answer A: No relationship since they operate independently.
Answer B: Unmetered fuel pressure affects both units.
Answer C: The accelerating pump actuates the enrichment valve.
Explanation (General): There are different types of pressure-injection carburetors that use different types of enrichment and accelerating systems.|The majority of pressure-injection carburetors use a balance between metered and unmetered fuel pressure to open the enrichment valve, and a balance between manifold pressure and spring force to actuate the accelerating pump.|The enrichment valve produces an increase of steady-state flow of fuel, while the accelerating pump provides a momentary increase in the fuel flow when the throttle is suddenly opened.

Question: What is the relationship between the pressure existing within the throat of a venturi and the velocity of the air passing through the venturi?
Answer A: There is no direct relationship between the pressure and the velocity.
Answer B: The pressure is directly proportional to the velocity.
Answer C: The pressure is inversely proportional to the velocity.
Explanation (General): The pressure in the throat of a venturi is inversely proportional to the velocity of the air flowing through it.|This is in accordance with Bernoulli's principle.

Question: Which of the following is least likely to occur during operation of an engine equipped with a direct cylinder fuel injection system?
Answer C: Backfiring.
Explanation (General): Backfiring, which is the ignition of the fuel-air mixture in the induction system of an engine during the time of valve overlap, is least likely to occur on an engine equipped with direct cylinder fuel injection. This is because there is no combustible fuel-air mixture in the induction system. The fuel is injected directly into the combustion chamber of the cylinder.|A direct cylinder fuel injection system is not to be confused with a continuous-flow fuel injection system.

Question: What carburetor component actually limits the desired maximum airflow to the engine at full throttle?
Answer C: Manifold intake.
Explanation (General): The venturi limits the maximum airflow into the engine at full throttle operation.|At conditions other than full throttle, the position of the butterfly-type throttle valve limits the amount of air.

Question: On a carburetor without an automatic mixture control as you ascend to altitude, the mixture will
Answer C: not be affected.
Explanation (General): If the carburetor does not have an automatic mixture control, the mixture ratio will become richer as the aircraft goes up in altitude and the air density becomes less.

Question: During engine operation, if carburetor heat is applied, it will
Answer C: decrease the air density to the carburetor.
Explanation (General): When carburetor heat is applied, the temperature of the air entering the engine is increased. Increasing its temperature decreases the density of the intake air.

Question: The desired engine idle speed and mixture setting
Answer A: is adjusted with engine warmed up and operating.
Answer B: should give minimum RPM with maximum manifold pressure.
Answer C: is usually adjusted in the following sequence; speed first, then mixture.
Explanation (General): Engine idle speed and mixture setting can be adjusted only when the engine is warmed up and operating properly.

Question: A nine-cylinder radial engine, using a multiple-point priming system with a central spider, will prime which cylinders?
Answer A: One, two, three, eight, and nine.
Answer C: One, three, five, and seven.
Explanation (General): A radial engine, using multiple-point priming, primes all of the cylinders above the center line of the engine.|In a nine-cylinder engine, these are cylinders 1, 2, 3, 8, and 9.

Question: What is a function of the idling air bleed in a float-type carburetor?
Answer A: It provides a means for adjusting the mixture at idle speeds.
Answer B: It vaporizes the fuel at idling speeds.
Answer C: It aids in emulsifying/vaporizing the fuel at idle speeds.
Explanation (General): The idle air bleed on a float-type carburetor aids in emulsifying the fuel drawn from the idle system during idle-speed operation.

Question: If the volume of air passing through a carburetor venturi is reduced, the pressure at the venturi throat will
Answer B: be equal to the pressure at the venturi outlet.
Answer C: increase.
Explanation (General): When the volume of air passing through the carburetor venturi is reduced by partially closing the throttle valve, the pressure at the venturi throat will increase.

Question: (Refer to Figure 6.) Which curve most nearly represents an aircraft engine's fuel/air ratio throughout its operating range?
Explanation (General): Curve 1 is not correct, because the mixture does not get progressively richer as the RPM increases.|Curve 2 is correct, because a richer mixture is provided for idling when scavenging is poor and also for full power operation when extra fuel is needed for cooling.|Curve 3 is not correct, because the actual mixture ratio needs are exactly opposite to that shown in this curve.|Curve 4 is not correct, because the mixture does not get progressively richer as the RPM increases.

Question: What will occur if the vapor vent float in a pressure carburetor loses its buoyancy?
Answer A: The amount of fuel returning to the fuel tank from the carburetor will be increased.
Answer B: The engine will continue to run after the mixture control is placed in IDLE CUTOFF.
Answer C: A rich mixture will occur at all engine speeds.
Explanation (General): The vapor vent floats in a pressure-injection carburetor ride on top of the fuel in chambers D and E.|When vapors collect in these chambers, the float drops down and opens the needle valve so fuel and vapors can return to the fuel tank.|If either float loses its buoyancy, the needle valve will remain off its seat and there will be a continuous flow of fuel back to the tank.|This return of fuel does not affect either the engine operation or the fuel consumption, but it does cause the flow indication to be incorrect.|In modern pressure carburetors, there are no floats or valves in this system, but a calibrated amount of fuel continually flows back into one of the tanks.

Question: What method is ordinarily used to make idle speed adjustments on a float-type carburetor?
Answer A: An adjustable throttle stop or linkage.
Answer B: An orifice and adjustable tapered needle.
Answer C: An adjustable needle in the drilled passageway which connects the airspace of the float chamber and the carburetor venturi.
Explanation (General): Idle speed adjustment on a float-type carburetor is made by adjusting the amount the throttle valve remains away from the throttle body wall when the throttle control is against its stop.|This adjustment is normally made with an adjustable throttle stop screw.

Question: For what primary purpose is a turbine engine fuel control unit trimmed?
Answer A: To obtain maximum thrust output when desired.
Answer B: To properly position the power levers.
Answer C: To adjust the idle RPM.
Explanation (General): The adjustments allowed to be made on a turbine engine are the adjustment of the idling RPM and the maximum RPM adjustment. These adjustments are commonly called trimming the engine.|An engine is trimmed to allow it to obtain maximum thrust output when it is desired.

Question: Which type of fuel control is used on most of today's turbine engines?
Answer C: Hydromechanical or electronic.
Explanation (General): Most of the modern fuel controls used on turbine engines are of the hydromechanical or electronic type.

Question: Under which of the following conditions will the trimming of a turbine engine be most accurate?
Answer C: No wind and low moisture.
Explanation (General): To accurately trim a turbine engine, which is the adjustment of the fuel control unit, there should be no wind to create an untrue pressure at the engine intake.|There should also be a low moisture content in the air. This is because moisture, or water vapor, is much less dense than standard (dry) air.

Question: (1) The mixture used at rated power in air cooled reciprocating engines is richer than the mixture used through the normal cruising range.|(2) The mixture used at idle in air cooled reciprocating engines is richer than the mixture used at rated power.|Regarding the above statements,
Answer C: both No. 1 and No. 2 are true.
Explanation (General): Statement (1) is true. The mixture ratio used when an engine is developing its rated horsepower is richer than the ratio used throughout the normal cruising range. The additional fuel is used for cooling.|Statement (2) is also true. The mixture used at idling is richer than the mixture used at rated power because incomplete scavenging and uneven mixture distribution during idle operation requires an excessively rich mixture.

Question: Under which of the following conditions would an engine run lean even though there is a normal amount of fuel present?
Answer A: The use of too high an octane rating fuel.
Answer C: The carburetor air heater valve in the HOT position.
Explanation (General): Incomplete fuel vaporization causes an excess of air for the amount of vaporized fuel.|Incomplete fuel vaporization causes an engine to operate lean even though a normal amount of fuel has been metered.

Question: During idle mixture adjustments, which of the following is normally observed to determine when the correct mixture has been achieved?
Answer C: Changes in RPM or manifold pressure.
Explanation (General): The correct idling mixture adjustments are determined by watching the changes in the RPM and the manifold pressure as the mixture control is slowly moved into the IDLE CUTOFF position.

Question: An indication that the optimum idle mixture has been obtained occurs when the mixture control is moved to IDLE CUTOFF and manifold pressure
Answer A: decreases momentarily and RPM drops slightly before the engine ceases to fire.
Answer B: increases momentarily and RPM drops slightly before the engine ceases to fire.
Answer C: decreases and RPM increases momentarily before the engine ceases to fire.
Explanation (General): The optimum idle mixture setting causes a slight decrease in the manifold pressure and a slight rise in RPM as the mixture control is pulled back into the IDLE CUTOFF position. These changes occur just before the engine stops firing.

Question: The use of less than normal throttle opening during starting will cause
Answer C: backfire due to lean fuel/air ratio.
Explanation (General): If the throttle is opened less than normal during the engine starting procedure, a rich mixture will be drawn into the cylinders.

Question: When checking the idle mixture on a carburetor, the engine should be idling normally, then pull the mixture control toward the IDLE CUTOFF position. A correct idling mixture will be indicated by
Answer B: a decrease of 20 to 30 RPM before quitting.
Answer C: an increase of 10 to 50 RPM before decreasing.
Explanation (General): The correct idling fuel-air mixture is indicated when there is a slight rise in RPM before the engine stops running as the mixture control is slowly moved into the IDLE CUTOFF position.

Question: When a new carburetor is installed on an engine,
Answer A: warm up the engine and adjust the float level.
Answer B: do not adjust the idle mixture setting; this was accomplished on the flow bench.
Answer C: and the engine is warmed up to normal temperatures, adjust the idle mixture, then the idle speed.
Explanation (General): After a new carburetor is installed on an aircraft engine, the engine must be warmed up to its normal operating temperature and the idle mixture and idle speed adjustments made.

Question: The purpose of the back-suction mixture control in a float-type carburetor is to adjust the mixture by
Answer A: regulating the pressure drop at the venturi.
Answer B: regulating the pressure on the fuel in the float chamber.
Answer C: regulating the suction on the mixture from behind the throttle valve.
Explanation (General): A back-suction mixture control in a float-type carburetor adjusts the fuel-air mixture ratio by regulating the air pressure on the fuel in the float bowl.|This pressure determines the fuel level at the discharge nozzle.

Question: Reciprocating engine power will be decreased at all altitudes if the
Answer C: manifold pressure is increased.
Explanation (General): An increase in humidity decreases the power produced by an engine, because the amount of power released from the fuel is determined by the mass of air mixed with the fuel when it is burned.|Water vapor is less dense than dry air, so humid air has less mass than an equal volume of dry air.

Question: If the idling jet becomes clogged in a float-type carburetor, the
Answer A: engine operation will not be affected at any RPM.
Answer C: idle mixture becomes richer.
Explanation (General): A float-type carburetor with a clogged idling jet will not provide fuel to the engine when the throttle is closed to the idle position.|The engine will not run at idle speeds.

Question: An aircraft engine equipped with a pressure-type carburetor is started with the
Answer A: primer while the mixture control is positioned at IDLE CUTOFF.
Answer B: mixture control in the FULL-RICH position.
Answer C: primer while the mixture control is positioned at the FULL-LEAN position.
Explanation (General): An engine equipped with a pressure carburetor is started with fuel supplied to the cylinders by the priming system.|The engine is started with the mixture control in the IDLE CUTOFF position.

Question: One of the best ways to increase engine power and control detonation and preignition is to
Answer C: lean the fuel/air mixture.
Explanation (General): A water-injection system (ADI system) is used to allow a reciprocating engine to operate with maximum power without detonation or preignition.

Question: An excessively lean fuel/air mixture may cause
Answer A: an increase in cylinder head temperature.
Answer C: backfiring through the exhaust.
Explanation (General): An excessively lean fuel-air mixture ratio burns slowly. It is still burning when the gases are forced out past the exhaust valve.|This slow burning will cause an increase in cylinder head temperature.

Question: The density of air is very important when mixing fuel and air to obtain a correct fuel-to-air ratio. Which of the following weighs the most?
Answer A: 75 parts of dry air and 25 parts of water vapor.
Answer C: 50 parts of dry air and 50 parts of water vapor.
Explanation (General): Water vapor weighs only about 5/8 as much as dry air. Therefore, 100 parts of dry air will weigh more than any of the other choices given with this question.

Question: A mixture ratio of 11:1 normally refers to
Answer C: 1 part fuel to 11 parts air.
Explanation (General): An air/fuel mixture ratio of 11:1 is a mixture of eleven parts of air and one part of fuel by weight.|An air-fuel ratio of 11:1 is the same as a fuel-air ratio of 0.091.

Question: The economizer system in a float-type carburetor
Answer B: functions only at cruise and idle speeds.
Answer C: increases the fuel/air ratio at high power settings.
Explanation (General): The economizer system in a float-type carburetor increases the fuel-air mixture ratio at high power settings.|By using the rich mixture only at the higher power settings, the engine can use an economically lean mixture during all other operations.

Question: A carburetor is prevented from leaning out during quick acceleration by the
Answer C: accelerating system.
Explanation (General): The accelerating system provides a momentarily rich mixture during quick acceleration of the engine to prevent its 'leaning out.'

Question: In turbine engines that utilize a pressurization and dump valve, the dump portion of the valve
Answer A: cuts off fuel flow to the engine fuel manifold and dumps the manifold fuel into the combustor to burn just before the engine shuts down.
Answer B: drains the engine manifold lines to prevent fuel boiling and subsequent deposits in the lines as a result of residual engine heat (at engine shutdown).
Answer C: dumps extra fuel into the engine in order to provide for quick engine acceleration during rapid throttle advancement.
Explanation (General): A fuel pressurization and dump valve is usually required on engines that incorporate duplex fuel nozzles to divide the flow into primary and main manifolds.|At the flow required for starting and for altitude idling, the pressurization valve is closed, and all of the fuel passes through the primary line.|At shut down, the dump valve drains the fuel manifold to prevent the fuel boiling as a result of residual engine heat. This boiling would leave solid deposits that could clog the calibrated passageways.

Question: What effect does high atmospheric humidity have on the operation of a jet engine?
Answer C: Has little or no effect.
Explanation (General): High atmospheric humidity, which affects reciprocating engine power appreciably, has little or no effect on a turbojet engine's thrust, fuel flow and RPM.

Question: What are the positions of the pressurization valve and the dump valve in a jet engine fuel system when the engine is shut down?
Answer A: Pressurization valve closed, dump valve open.
Answer B: Pressurization valve open, dump valve open.
Answer C: Pressurization valve closed, dump valve closed.
Explanation (General): When a turbojet engine is shut down, the pressurization valve is closed and the dump valve is open.

Question: What could cause a lean mixture and high cylinder head temperature at sea level or low altitudes?
Answer C: Automatic mixture control stuck in the extended position.
Explanation (General): If the needle valve in an automatic mixture control in a pressure-injection carburetor sticks while it is in its extended position, it can cause a lean mixture and a high cylinder head temperature.

Question: Which of the following is NOT an input parameter for a turbine engine fuel control unit?
Answer C: Ambient humidity.
Explanation (General): Jet engine fuel control units often monitor the engine or high-pressure compressor speed, the compressor inlet pressure and temperature, compressor discharge pressure, and burner can pressure. Ambient humidity is not a controlling factor.

Question: Detonation occurs when the fuel/air mixture
Answer B: ignites before the time of normal ignition.
Answer C: is too rich.
Explanation (General): Detonation causes high cylinder head temperatures because the fuel-air mixture burns too fast.|In detonation, the fuel-air mixture actually explodes rather than burning evenly as it should.

Question: What corrective action should be taken when a carburetor is found to be leaking fuel from the discharge nozzle?
Answer A: Replace the needle valve and seat.
Answer C: Turn the fuel off each time the aircraft is parked.
Explanation (General): If a float-type carburetor is leaking fuel from the discharge nozzle when the engine is not running, it is probably because the needle valve in the float bowl is leaking.|The needle valve and the seat should be replaced.

Question: A major difference between the Teledyne-Continental and RSA (Precision Airmotive or Bendix) continuous flow fuel injection systems in fuel metering is that the
Answer A: RSA system uses air pressure only as a metering force.
Answer B: Continental system utilizes airflow as a metering force.
Answer C: Continental system uses fuel pressure only as a metering force.
Explanation (General): The RSA continuous-flow fuel injection system uses a balance of air and fuel forces to provide the correct pressure drop across the main metering jet for all engine operating conditions except idling.|The Teledyne-Continental system does not use any air metering force, but rather it produces a fuel pressure across the metering jet that is proportional to the engine speed. This accurate pressure is produced by an engine-driven vane-type pump and a calibrated bypass orifice.

Question: The function of the altitude compensating, or aneroid valve used with the Teledyne-Continental fuel injection system on many turbocharged engines is to
Answer A: prevent an overly rich mixture during sudden acceleration.
Answer C: provide a means of enriching the mixture during sudden acceleration.
Explanation (General): When the throttle of a turbocharged engine is opened suddenly, the engine accelerates faster than the turbocharger is able to increase the upper deck pressure. As a result the fuel-air mixture becomes excessively rich.|The Teledyne-Continental fuel injection system solves this problem by controlling the bypass orifice with an aneroid that senses upper deck or turbocharger discharge pressure. When the engine accelerates and the pump output pressure increases, the aneroid holds the bypass orifice open and allows the excess fuel to return to the inlet side of the pump until the upper deck pressure increases. Then, the aneroid decreases the size of the orifice and allows the pressure, and thus the flow to increase.

Question: The primary purpose of the air bleed openings used with continuous flow fuel injector nozzles is to
Answer C: aid in proper fuel vaporization.
Explanation (General): The injector nozzles used with a continuous-flow fuel injection system have air bleed holes that allow air to be drawn into the nozzle to aid in the vaporization of the fuel that is being injected into the intake valve port.

Question: During what period does the fuel pump bypass valve open and remain open?
Answer A: When the fuel pump pressure is greater than the demand of the engine.
Answer B: When the boost pump pressure is greater than fuel pump pressure.
Answer C: When the fuel pump output is greater than the demand of the carburetor.
Explanation (General): The bypass valve around the vanes of a vane-type engine-driven fuel pump opens and remains open any time the boost pump pressure is greater than the fuel pump discharge pressure.

Question: Which of the following statements concerning a centrifugal-type fuel boost pump located in a fuel supply tank is NOT true?
Answer A: Air and fuel vapors do not pass through a centrifugal-type pump.
Answer B: Fuel can be drawn through the impeller section of the pump when it is not in operation.
Answer C: The centrifugal-type pump is classified as a positive displacement pump.
Explanation (General): A centrifugal pump is not a positive-displacement pump.|A positive-displacement pump is one that moves a constant volume of fluid each time it revolves. A centrifugal pump can rotate without pumping any fuel if its discharge is obstructed.

Question: Where is the engine fuel shutoff valve usually located?
Answer C: Downstream of the engine-driven fuel pump.
Explanation (General): According to 14 CFR 23.995, certificated aircraft must not have their fuel shutoff valves located on the engine side of the firewall.

Question: Boost pumps in a fuel system
Answer B: are primarily used for fuel transfer.
Answer C: provide a positive flow of fuel to the engine pump.
Explanation (General): Boost pumps in an aircraft fuel tank are primarily used to provide a positive flow of fuel to the engine fuel pump.|Boost pumps are also used to transfer fuel, but this is not their primary function.

Question: (Refer to Figure 7.) What is the purpose of the fuel transfer ejectors?
Answer A: To supply fuel under pressure to the engine-driven pump.
Answer B: To assist in the transfer of fuel from the main tank to the boost pump sump.
Answer C: To transfer fuel from the boost pump sump to the wing tank.
Explanation (General): The fuel transfer ejectors provide a venturi effect in the main fuel tank to facilitate the flow of fuel from the tank into the boost pump sump.

Question: What is the purpose of an engine-driven fuel pump bypass valve?
Answer A: To divert the excess fuel back to the main tank.
Answer B: To prevent a damaged or inoperative pump from blocking the fuel flow of another pump in series with it.
Answer C: To divert the excess fuel from the pressure side of the pump to the inlet side of the pump.
Explanation (General): Almost all vane-type engine-driven fuel pumps have a pump bypass valve through which fuel can flow when the pump is not operating.|This bypass valve allows fuel from the booster pump to reach the engine for starting and in case the engine-driven pump fails.

Question: Most large aircraft reciprocating engines are equipped with which of the following types of engine-driven fuel pumps?
Answer C: Gear-type fuel pump.
Explanation (General): Rotary-vane pumps are the type most generally used as fuel pumps for large reciprocating engines.

Question: When an electric primer is used, fuel pressure is built up by the
Answer A: internal pump in the primer solenoid.
Answer B: suction at the main discharge nozzle.
Answer C: booster pump.
Explanation (General): When an electric primer is used to start an aircraft engine, the fuel pressure is built up by the booster pump.

Question: The fuel pump relief valve directs excess fuel to the
Answer B: inlet side of the fuel pump.
Answer C: inlet side of the fuel strainer.
Explanation (General): Aircraft-engine fuel pumps have a built-in relief valve that directs the excess fuel back to the inlet side of the pump.

Question: Which type of pump is commonly used as a fuel pump on reciprocating engines?
Answer C: Vane.
Explanation (General): The vane-type pump is the most commonly used fuel pump on reciprocating engines.

Question: The purpose of the diaphragm in most vane-type fuel pumps is to
Answer A: maintain fuel pressure below atmospheric pressure.
Answer B: equalize fuel pressure at all speeds.
Answer C: compensate fuel pressures to altitude changes.
Explanation (General): The diaphragm in a vane-type fuel pump is acted upon by the atmospheric air pressure to maintain the output pressure from the pump at a constant value above the ambient air pressure.

Question: The primary condition(s) that allow(s) microorganisms to grow in the fuel in aircraft fuel tanks is (are)
Answer C: the presence of dirt or other particulate contaminants.
Explanation (General): Microorganisms of various types can grow in an aircraft fuel tank and in storage tanks if water is present.|The microorganisms live in the water and feed on the hydrocarbon fuel.

Question: It is desirable that fuel lines have a gentle slope upward or downward and not have sharp curves or sharp rises and/or falls in order to
Answer B: prevent stagnation or 'pooling' of fuel in the fuel lines.
Answer C: minimize the generation of static electricity by decreasing fluid friction in the lines.
Explanation (General): Fuel lines should have sufficient size to carry the maximum required fuel flow under all operating conditions, and should have no sharp curves or sharp rises and/or falls which would trap vapors and cause vapor lock. Fuel lines should also be kept away from hot parts of the engine and exhaust system.

Question: The fuel systems of aircraft certificated in the standard classification must include which of the following?
Answer A: An engine-driven fuel pump and at least one auxiliary pump per engine.
Answer B: A positive means of shutting off the fuel to all engines.
Answer C: A reserve supply of fuel, available to the engine only after selection by the flightcrew, sufficient to operate the engines at least 30 minutes at METO power.
Explanation (General): All aircraft fuel systems must have some positive means of shutting the fuel off to all of the engines.

Question: Where should the main fuel strainer be located in the aircraft fuel system?
Answer A: Downstream from the wobble pump check valve.
Answer B: At the lowest point in the fuel system.
Answer C: At any point in the system lower than the carburetor strainer.
Explanation (General): The main fuel strainer in an aircraft should be located at the lowest point in the fuel system so it can collect foreign matter from the line between the tank and the engine and where it can also serve as a water trap.

Question: Where physical separation of the fuel lines from electrical wiring or conduit is impracticable, locate the fuel line
Answer A: below the wiring and clamp the line securely to the airframe structure.
Answer B: above the wiring and clamp the line securely to the airframe structure.
Answer C: inboard of the wiring and clamp both securely to the airframe structure.
Explanation (General): If fuel lines and electrical wire bundles must be routed through the same compartment, the fuel line must be below the wiring to prevent fuel from dripping into the wiring if the fuel line should leak.|The wire bundle must be securely fastened to the airframe structure, never to the fuel line.

Question: What is a characteristic of a centrifugal-type fuel boost pump?
Answer A: It separates air and vapor from the fuel.
Answer C: It requires a relief valve.
Explanation (General): A centrifugal-type boost pump, located in a fuel tank, separates the air and vapor from the fuel before the fuel is forced out of the tank through the fuel line.|The vapors rise to the top of the tank.

Question: The Federal Aviation Regulations require the fuel flow rate for gravity systems (main and reserve) to be
Answer A: 125 percent of the takeoff fuel consumption of the engine.
Answer B: 125 percent of the maximum, except takeoff, fuel consumption of the engine.
Answer C: 150 percent of the takeoff fuel consumption of the engine.
Explanation (General): 14 CFR 23.955(b) states that the fuel flow rate for gravity systems (main and reserve supply) must be 150% of the takeoff fuel consumption of the engine.

Question: Fuel boost pumps are operated
Answer A: to provide a positive flow of fuel to the engine.
Answer C: primarily for fuel transfer to another tank.
Explanation (General): Fuel boost pumps are operated to provide a positive flow of fuel to the engine for starting and for high-altitude operation when there is a possibility of vapor lock.|They are also used in many installations to transfer fuel.

Question: A pilot reports that the fuel pressure fluctuates and exceeds the upper limits whenever the throttle is advanced. The most likely cause of the trouble is
Answer A: a ruptured fuel pump relief-valve diaphragm.
Answer B: a sticking fuel pump relief valve.
Answer C: an air leak at the fuel pump relief-valve body.
Explanation (General): Fluctuating fuel pressure and pressure that sometimes exceeds the upper limits for the fuel pressure can be caused by a sticky relief valve in the fuel pump.

Question: A fuel strainer or filter must be located between the
Answer B: tank outlet and the fuel metering device.
Answer C: boost pump and engine-driven fuel pump.
Explanation (General): According to 14 CFR 23.997, there must be a fuel strainer or filter between the fuel tank outlet and the inlet of either the fuel metering device or an engine-driven, positive-displacement fuel pump, whichever is nearer the fuel tank outlet.

Question: Fuel pump relief valves designed to compensate for atmospheric pressure variations are known as
Answer C: balanced-type relief valves.
Explanation (General): A balanced-type relief valve uses carburetor upper-deck pressure acting on a diaphragm in the pressure relief valve to maintain the fuel pressure at a given amount above the carburetor-inlet air pressure.

Question: Fuel lines are kept away from sources of heat, and sharp bends and steep rises are avoided to reduce the possibility of
Answer C: positive lock.
Explanation (General): A vapor lock is a condition in a fuel line in which fuel vapors become trapped in a bend.|If the vapor pressure of the trapped fuel is higher than the fuel pressure, no fuel can flow to the carburetor.|Sharp bends and steep rises should be avoided, and fuel lines should not be routed in an area where the fuel can absorb heat.

Question: Fuel crossfeed systems are used in aircraft to
Answer C: maintain aircraft stability.
Explanation (General): The main purpose of a fuel cross-feed system in a multi-engine aircraft is to allow any engine to operate from any fuel tank.|In case one engine fails, the cross-feed system allows the fuel from all of the tanks to be used evenly. This helps maintain aircraft stability.

Question: If an engine equipped with a float-type carburetor backfires or misses when the throttle is advanced, a likely cause is that the
Answer C: accelerating pump is not operating properly.
